oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Bill Ivey interviewed by Terry Gross on "Fresh Air"
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: The recording is of Bill Ivey being interviewed by Terry Gross. The recording is on the show "Fresh Air."
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Bill Ivey
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: Side One - (0:00) -- Terry Gross' introduction of Bill Ivey. The senate confirmed Bill Ivey as the head of National Endowment For The Arts. Bill Ivey put together a three CD box set covering the years 1927-1995 celebrating African-Americans in country music. (0:56) -- A snippet of the song "(I'm So) Afraid Of Losing You Again" by Charley Pride. (2:24) -- Terry Gross asks Bill Ivey what his goals were when putting this box set together. (4:00) -- Terry Gross introduction of the track "He's In The Jailhouse Now" by the Memphis Sheiks, a cover of a Jimmie Rodgers song. (5:47) -- Bill Ivey speaks on Jimmie Rodgers' writing influence on performers. (6:24) -- "He's In The Jailhouse Now" by the Memphis Sheiks in 1930. (7:24) -- Terry Gross asks Bill Ivey about what elements white performers would take from black performers and vice versa. (9:20) -- Bill Ivey speaks about the role of the fiddle in songwriting during the 1930's. (10:42) -- Terry Gross speaks about the production of 'race' and 'hillbilly' records in the 1940's. Terry Gross asks Bill Ivey about his opinion on that terminology. (12:28) -- Bill Ivey explains why the terms 'race' and 'hillbilly' were initially chosen by record companies. (13:22) -- Terry Gross asks about CD #2 of Bill Ivey's box set. (15:34) -- Bill Ivey mentions the importance of The Grand Ole Opry, WLS Barn Dance, and The Louisiana Hayride. (16:04) -- Bill Ivey chooses his favorite recording from his box set, Ivory Joe Hunter's performance of "He'll Never Love You." (17:04) -- Ivory Joe Hunter's performance of "He'll Never Love You" on the Grand Ole Opry. (19:55) -- Interview resumes. (20:17) -- Terry Gross asks Bill Ivey about CD #3 of his box set emphasizing Charley Pride. (21:42) -- Terry Gross asks about the recording of LaMelle Prince - "A Man That Made A Woman Out Of Me." LaMelle Prince worked with Owen Bradley at Decca. (23:34) -- LaMelle Prince's "A Man That Made A Woman Out Of Me." (24:49) -- Terry Gross asks Bill Ivey about the possible impact he desires this box set to have. (27:39) -- Solomon Burke - "Just Out Of Reach."
